p.s: As we have learned in the first exercise, the excerpt taken from the novel Gun Love, by Jennifer Clement and published in 2019, deals with Helen, a lonely foster child who has never experienced real love and care.
Helen is a very tiny eight year old girl (comp. ll. 1-2).
She is so small that she looked about five (l. 2).
There is no existing family or a real friend.
Helen has no idea who she (is) or where she (comes) from (ll. 5-6).
The fact that she invents all the time new family members and places where she so-called lived (comp. ll. 6-10), shows, how much she dreams of a family.
It underlines her loneliness.
In addition to that, Helen invents very special things about her past: that she had for example Jehova's Witness homes (l. 10).
She tries to say something interesting.
To get attention on the one hand and to underline her special past and experiences on the other hand.
With this, the author intends to convey the impression that she actually is a very lonely person, but tries to be aas positive she can.
Helen has at least seventeen phones (l. 26) of her past foster homes because everybody says she should stay in touch, it can be assumed that they do not expect and want it actually.
The problem is, that Helen does not know which phone belongs to which house (comp. l. 28).
These facts show how much lifeslives and houses she had.
Every was the same.
But Helen has kept them, she does not want to leave her past families go.
In addition to that she does not have real friends.
Helen talks from best friends (l. 33) she wants to call.
But by the fact that she wants to talk with them about topics like do you like cats? (l. 34) you can assume that these friends are only inventions of her head.
You do not ask friends questions like this, when you are this close.
These characteristic shows how much Helen searches for relationships with other people.
For people in her surrounding, her lies are probably not a sign of evilness, they are rather sad.

The other foster children are important to her, she tries to be very close to them (comp. l. 41).
In general, how she seems to other people, Helen is a very sweet person.
Pearl describes that Helen (smells) like burned marshmallows (l. 3).
With this she uses the marshmallows as a symbol.
When you analyse her behaviour, her most dominant characteristic you have to focus on is the fact that she (talks) nonstop (l. 5).

The fact that Helen searches for love can be proven through several aspects.

To solve this problem, she talks a lot and invents things.
